message_1: Determine whether the following statement is true or false: "If a triangle has two equal angles, then it is isosceles." Provide a proof to support your answer.
message_2:
The statement is true. If a triangle has two equal angles, then it is an isosceles triangle. Here's a proof to support the answer:

Proof:

Let's consider a triangle ABC, where angle A and angle B are equal, i.e., ∠A = ∠B.

According to the Angle-Side relationship theorem (also known as the Converse of the Corresponding Angles Postulate), if two angles of a triangle are congruent, then the sides opposite to those angles are congruent as well.

In our triangle ABC, since ∠A = ∠B, the sides opposite to these angles will also be congruent. That is, side AC will be congruent to side BC, i.e., AC = BC.

Since two sides of the triangle are congruent (AC = BC), the triangle ABC is an isosceles triangle by definition.

Hence, the statement "If a triangle has two equal angles, then it is isosceles" is true.
